comments:
EAS 401 introduces students to one of the most dominating and compelling areas
of human existence and endeavor: energy, with its foundations in technology, association
to economics, and impacts on ecology and society. The course spans from basic
principles to applications through a review of energy consumption, use, and resources;
ecological impacts, sustainability and design of sustainable energy systems; methods of
energy analysis; forecasting; electricity generation systems (steam and gas turbine based
power plants, fuel cells), energy for transportation (cars, aircraft, and ships); nuclear
energy and wastes; renewable energy use: solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal,
biomass; and prospects for future energy systems: fusion power, power generation in
space.
Course content overall was “very interesting and informative,” but the methods of
learning it “were not very exciting.” This course is heavily geared toward upperclassmen
engineers, so those not in their final years of college or not in engineering struggled more
than others.
Many students felt that Professor Lior was an “awesome instructor” and taught a
“great class.” The topics he gave out to write papers on were well received by the
students.
The main complaint for this class was that the workload is very bottom-heavy,
meaning that in the last third of the semester, two 50 page papers, 5 homework
assignments, and a final were all assigned. Students wished this were spread out more so
that they could plan better for the end of the semester. However, students viewed this as
a “valuable experience” and appreciate the skills learned from this course.
